question: Prayer is obligatory in all circumstances, especially in times of distress. - Even if war were chosen, prayer should precede it.  Therefore, making prayer sound merely conditional conflicts with its mandatory nature

The words of the Midrash mentioned above (in the previous drush) can be explained: "And Judah approached him" - Rabbi Yehuda says it was an approach for war, Rabbi Nechemia says it was an approach for appeasement, etc., and the Rabbis say it was an approach for prayer - and all these are the words of the living G-d. All these aspects were included in his words.

As we explained regarding Joseph's words, besides their simple meaning, the inner meaning of the words contained hints to lofty and hidden matters. Similarly were Judah's words, as written in the holy sefer Noam Elimelech (in Parshat Vayishlach) on the verse "Thus shall you say to my master, to Esau: 'I have sojourned with Laban, etc.'"

He [the Noam Elimelech] questioned why Jacob needed to mention and call Esau "my master" when speaking to the angels in his house. Also, the letter "lamed" in "l'Esau" (to Esau) seems unnecessary - he should have said "adoni Esau" (my master Esau). Furthermore, regarding Rashi's explanation that "I have sojourned with Laban" means "I kept the 613 mitzvot," would this really find favor in Esau's eyes?

Rather, the matter is that when a tzaddik speaks with people, he is precise in his words, ensuring that his words are heard in their simple meaning by the person he's speaking with, while the main content he intends with those words is prayer and supplication before HaKadosh Baruch Hu. The intention is to hide his words of prayer within the conversation he has with the person, and he doesn't explicitly state his needed prayer in order that the prosecutor (satan) won't understand his intention and won't prosecute him.

This is what Jacob said to the angels: "Thus shall you say" - in this manner and with this intention you should say all your words - "to my master," meaning your intention should be to the Master of All, the Blessed Creator, while also having a simple meaning for Esau that would be pleasing to him. This is why it says "Thus says your servant Jacob: 'I have sojourned with Laban,'" which can be understood in two ways: as words of advocacy before Hashem that he kept the 613 mitzvot, and this merit should protect him from Esau, and also in its simple meaning as words of appeasement and submission to Esau, that he was merely a stranger and didn't become important or powerful, as Rashi explains.

Similarly can be explained Judah's words to Joseph when he said "Please, my master, let your servant speak a word in my master's ears." When he mentioned "my master," the inner content of his words was prayer and supplication before the Creator, speaking words toward Above, but he concealed and clothed in his words also the simple meaning that would be words of appeasement and harsh words to Joseph. This explains well what our Sages said in the Midrash that this approach was for appeasement and for war with Joseph according to the simple meaning, and an approach of prayer to the Creator as mentioned above.

The explanation appears to be that in truth, the law that a conditional nidui (excommunication) requires annulment applies to every person. However, specifically regarding Yehudah, we needed the additional reason that a chacham's (sage's) curse comes to pass even when conditional. Nevertheless, Chazal (our Sages) correctly learned from Yehudah's case that for every person, a conditional nidui requires annulment, even if the one declaring it isn't a chacham, as will be explained further.

The Tosafot's position (mentioned earlier) is that Yehudah's nidui took effect despite fulfilling his condition, because it was initially conditioned on something that wasn't entirely in his control - perhaps Yosef would prevent it, or disaster might befall them on the way. Therefore, the nidui took effect from the beginning even though it was conditional.

According to their words, one might ask why didn't Yaakov and Yehudah annul the nidui, since in such cases it requires annulment? However, in truth, Yehudah knew through ruach hakodesh (Divine inspiration) that he would be able to fulfill his condition, and no disaster would befall them on the way, but rather he would return Binyamin to his father as he had accepted upon himself in his guarantee. It's explained in Midrashim that the holy Shevatim (tribes) knew everything that would happen to Israel until the end of generations, and certainly Yehudah knew through ruach hakodesh about what lay before him - that he would be able to fulfill his condition. For this reason, he accepted the guarantee upon himself.

According to his knowledge through ruach hakodesh, he didn't need annulment at all, as Tosafot wrote that when one has the ability to fulfill the condition, the nidui doesn't take effect from the start. Similarly with Yosef, once they verified through seeing his milah (circumcision) that he was a tzaddik (righteous person), they then believed in the sign of his speech when he spoke in Lashon Hakodesh (the Holy Tongue/Hebrew). Also, his speech was visible to the physical sense of sight. However, one cannot believe in a sign alone, as it's possible to perform signs through kishuf (sorcery) and magic, as the Rambam z"l wrote.

Therefore, there is no proof from here that two intermediate simanim (signs) are effective everywhere like a distinct siman muvhak (clear sign), as it's possible they wouldn't be effective elsewhere. Here they only believed him because of two signs: since they saw he was a tzaddik, they believed him based on the signs, similar to how the Torah commands us to believe based on a chazakah (presumption) if someone is established as great and wise.

In this way, we have assurance that a navi (prophet) will always be verified, and from Heaven they won't allow him to lie in this manner. Therefore, the tribes relied on these two signs. Furthermore, here the signs were clear and distinct - there was clear proof of his righteousness from showing them he was circumcised, and they saw the Divine Presence resting upon him. From seeing his language, it became clear to them that his mouth and heart were aligned, and he wouldn't change his speech even for the sake of Heaven, as mentioned above.

Therefore, since the signs were clear and distinct, the tribes relied upon them. However, there is no proof from here regarding signs that aren't distinct, and this doesn't pose a difficulty to those who disagree with the Masas Binyamin mentioned above.

We can explain the words of the Midrash (mentioned earlier in the previous discourse) on "And you shall go up in peace to your father." They said to him that this peace is entirely "nishpah" (the Yefat To'ar explains this as darkness, like "neshef" in Scripture, meaning this is a peace of darkness and gloom). Yet the Ruach HaKodesh [Divine Spirit] calls out "Great peace have they who love Your Torah."

This can be explained according to our approach: Yehudah and Yosef were arguing with each other, and the opposition between them was so great that Yehudah wanted to destroy all of Egypt, as explained by our Sages. Therefore, they said this peace is entirely "nishpah" - how can this be called peace when it is a peace of darkness and gloom?

However, all their arguments were for the sake of truth, and "both these and these are the words of the living God." Their disagreement was regarding halacha [Jewish law] and according to the laws of the Torah, as explained by the Pardes and other commentators. Such a disagreement will ultimately lead to peace, as indeed happened with them.

This is what the Ruach HaKodesh means by "Great peace have they who love Your Torah" - this is true peace when each of the disputants' desire and goal is only to understand the true meaning of the holy Torah. This is what the Midrash Tanchuma means when it says "And he sent Yehudah before him... yesterday they were butting heads with each other, and now he sends him to him - this exemplifies 'He who makes peace in His heights.'" Regarding what the Rambam z"l wrote (in Hilchos Yesodei HaTorah, Chapter 7) that one who believes solely based on signs (otot) has doubt in his heart, because it's possible that the sign was performed through sorcery or magic. Even though this isn't absolute proof, and people might err in considering someone righteous - for man only sees with his eyes - since the Torah commanded us to believe in such a case, and the Torah wouldn't lead us astray, this mitzvah serves as a guarantee that with these two signs (being worthy and performing wonders), a prophet will always be verified. One can further explain based on the holy Ramban's words on the verse "And Israel journeyed with all that he had, and came to Beer-sheba, and offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac." This verse contains a secret, etc. The text specifies "sacrifices" to inform us that these were not burnt offerings like his forefathers offered. For Abraham offered burnt offerings, and our Rabbis said that the children of Noah did not offer peace offerings but burnt offerings, and regarding Noah it explicitly states "and he offered burnt offerings on the altar." But Jacob, out of fear of Hashem, offered peace offerings (shelamim) to harmonize all the divine attributes, as they interpreted that shelamim brings peace (shalom) to the world.

Although he hints at lofty secrets in his words, we must also understand them according to their simple meaning. The explanation is that each tzaddik serves Hashem through a different attribute and aspect. Thus, Yehudah and Yosef each had different spiritual attributes, as our Sages alluded to when they said "this one is an ox and this one is a lion." Yaakov Avinu wanted to make peace between these two attributes, therefore when he went to Egypt and sent Yehudah ahead - yesterday the lion and ox were fighting and now he sends him to him - he offered peace offerings to harmonize the attributes of Yehudah and Yosef.

Similarly, one can say that when Yehudah approached Yosef, he recognized that Yosef's attribute was different from his own, and he wanted to make peace between the two attributes. For this reason, he offered peace offerings to harmonize their attributes. Remarkably, the holy Zohar states that the same unification that was achieved through the sacrifices was accomplished then by Yehudah and Yosef. Following our approach, one could say that Yehudah actually offered a sacrifice when he approached Yosef, thereby seeking to make peace between the two attributes. It can be explained by first considering the words of the holy Zohar (beginning of Parshat Vayigash): "And Judah approached him, etc. Rabbi Elazar began... Come and see, when the Holy One, Blessed be He, created the world, etc. When the sixth day came and it was necessary to create man, the Torah came before Him and said: 'This man that You wish to create will anger You in the future. At first glance, we need to understand the connection between this teaching and the verse "And Judah approached him." This can be explained according to the Gemara (Rosh Hashanah 17b) which teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, wrapped Himself like a prayer leader and showed Moses the order of prayer, saying: "Whenever Israel sins, let them perform before Me in this order, and I will forgive them."

The early authorities investigated whether merely reciting the Thirteen Attributes of Mercy is sufficient, or if one must actually embody these attributes in practice, as it is said "Cleave to His attributes - just as He is merciful, etc." In any case, it certainly helps, as the Midrash states "Hashem is your shadow" - meaning that the Holy One, Blessed be He, deals with man as a shadow, and with the measure one uses, they are measured.

The Midrash relates that at that moment, Judah tried to draw his sword from its sheath but could not. Judah said, "Surely this one (Joseph) fears Heaven." Perhaps Judah thought that the reason Joseph wasn't immediately punished (as Pharaoh was regarding Sarah our mother) was because he had merits and the Holy One, Blessed be He, was being patient with him. Therefore, he said to him "for you are like Pharaoh" with two comparative "kafs" - meaning that if another person would act as you do, they would be punished immediately like Pharaoh, but because you have fear of Heaven, the Holy One, Blessed be He, is patient with you, though you will ultimately be punished if you don't return him (Benjamin).

This is what is meant by "let not your anger burn" - although it would be appropriate for your anger to burn, conduct yourself with the attribute of patience, and then the Holy One, Blessed be He, will treat you with this same attribute. He gave the reason "for you are like Pharaoh" - that you deserve to be punished immediately like Pharaoh, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, is patient, and this is only if you too conduct yourself with this attribute.

According to the second interpretation, he said: "If you provoke me, I will kill you..." Because in truth, you deserve to be punished immediately for this act of theft, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, is patient with you. However, if you provoke me and don't conduct yourself with patience, then your punishment will come immediately and I will kill you and your master, and you won't be protected from Heaven to prevent your death.

Similarly, Bilaam had an argument that the Holy One Blessed be He permitted him through an angel who told him "Rise and go with them." So why did the angel stand against him to prevent his journey? Rather, because Bilaam wanted to go, an angel was created to lead him, as explained by the Maharsha on Chazal's statement (Makkot 10b) "In the way a person wishes to go, they lead him." The meaning is that from every thought a person thinks to do, an angel is created - whether for good or for bad.

Immediately when a person thinks in his mind to commit a sin, an angel is created from it, which then compels him to bring his thought from potential to actual deed. The Pri Megadim in his work "Matan Secharan Shel Mitzvot" wrote: "Through a sin that one commits, a destructive force (Mashchit) is created. One sin leads to another similar sin, and it compels him to such an extent that free will is almost nullified regarding that sin. By the second and third time, he is practically forced because the destructive force he created compels him. Nevertheless, since it began with his own will, he is liable under the laws of indirect damage (dinei d'garmi) because the damage is certain."

Therefore, even though Bilaam had the argument that the angel told him "Rise and go with them," this only came about because he created a destructive force through his evil will, and one sin led to another, for which he is liable under the laws of indirect damage, as the Pri Megadim explained.

We can explain the verse "to establish for you a remnant in the land, etc." based on what is said in the Gemara regarding ribis (interest) [Bava Metzia 75b]: Those who transgress the negative commandment are the lender, borrower, guarantor, and witnesses. Abaye said the lender transgresses all [prohibitions], etc., while the guarantor and witnesses only transgress "you shall not place upon him interest."

The Gemara [62a] asks: While all others perform an action, what action do the witnesses perform? Rather, is it not that the very act of establishing [the loan] is significant? Thus, even though the guarantor and witnesses didn't perform an actual deed in the matter itself, because the transaction was completed through them, they are liable for the prohibition of "you shall not place," with the root of the action being included in the word "placing."

Similarly, in our matter, Yosef HaTzaddik preceded going to Egypt to prepare a place for Bnei Yisrael so they could maintain their kedushah (holiness) in Egyptian exile, which was the ervat ha'aretz (most defiled land) and extremely contaminated. Through the power of his kedushah and the trials he withstood and overcame, and by becoming ruler over the sar (angel) of Egypt, he weakened the power of tumah (impurity) and klipot (negative forces) at their root.

Through this, Israel merited to be protected from immorality in Egypt - "Bnei Yisrael entered and Bnei Yisrael left" - and not one of them was born from improper relations, as our Sages said. Moreover, Yosef HaTzaddik prepared a power of salvation for future generations until the final exile, so that Israel could overcome and withstand the trials of exile and maintain their kedushah even in the terrible lowliness of ikveta d'meshicha (the footsteps of Mashiach), as the Egyptian exile is the root of all exiles.

The holy Avot and Shevatim were the root of all Jewish souls throughout the generations, and whatever exists in the branch exists in the root. Therefore, through their holy actions, they opened a channel and prepared strength for all generations of Israel. This is the meaning of "to establish for you a remnant in the land and to sustain you for a great deliverance" - that Yosef HaTzaddik established a foundation and root of strength for all generations of Israel. This is the holy spark which is hidden within the nefesh (soul) of every Jew, inherited from our holy forefathers. One can explain the verse "Your eyes see... for it is my mouth speaking to you," which Chazal interpret as "as my mouth is, so is my heart." In the previous verse it states "I will sustain you there... for there are yet five years of famine, lest you come to poverty, you, and your household, and all that you have." However, seemingly Yosef's promise to feed and sustain them for five more years wasn't fulfilled, as Chazal say that when Yaakov Avinu came to Egypt, the famine immediately ceased in his merit.

It's possible that Yosef knew through Ruach HaKodesh (Divine inspiration) that the famine would end with Yaakov's arrival, as Chazal say in Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer that Ruach HaKodesh guided him from his youth until his death. If so, why did he say "I will sustain you... for five more years of famine" when his vow wasn't fulfilled?

However, we have a principle that one shouldn't rely on miracles. Therefore, Yosef HaTzaddik empathized with their suffering and took upon himself wholeheartedly to feed and sustain them for five years. For this, he already received reward for all five years even though the famine ended earlier, as explained in the aforementioned Sifri that one receives reward for the declaration even if unable to complete the action.

So his brothers wouldn't question how he was permitted to make such a vow, since it's forbidden to make vows except by saying "Harei Zu" (behold this is), we explained earlier that it's permitted with proper intention. Therefore, he immediately said "Your eyes see... my mouth speaking to you," which Chazal interpret as "as my mouth is, so is my heart" - meaning his thoughts and intentions were proper, and in such a case it's a mitzvah to make a vow and one receives reward for the declaration as if for the action.

There are those who think that maintaining a large institution with great expenses through limited means and a small number of God-fearing supporters is anyway miraculous, and therefore rely on miracles, thinking they don't need to take action as the miracle will come regardless. But this isn't correct, as we don't rely on miracles. Only through the power of Jews giving with self-sacrifice and proper intention can we exist beyond natural means.

We can explain the verse "And to his father he sent 'like this' (k'zos): ten donkeys carrying from the best of Egypt, etc." The commentators were precise about the seemingly superfluous word "k'zos" (like this), as it would have been sufficient to say "and to his father he sent ten donkeys, etc."

This hints at our approach, based on what appears in the Midrash Rabbah (Parshas Acharei) on the verse "With this (b'zos) shall Aaron enter the Holy," which connects to the verse "L'David Hashem ori v'yishi (The Lord is my light and my salvation)." The Rabbis interpreted this verse regarding Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur - "ori" (my light) refers to Rosh Hashanah, and "yishi" (my salvation) to Yom Kippur. Throughout the year, the Satan accuses, but on Yom Kippur he cannot accuse. Israel said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: "Even if an army of Samael encamps against me, my heart will not fear, for You promised me 'With this shall Aaron enter the Holy.'"

Further in the Midrash, Rabbi Yudan interpreted the verse regarding the Kohen Gadol's entry into the Holy of Holies, saying he had many bundles of mitzvos in his merit: The merit of Torah ("And this is the Torah"), the merit of circumcision ("This is My covenant"), the merit of Shabbos ("Fortunate is the man who does this"), the merit of the tribes ("And this is what their father spoke to them"), the merit of terumah, the merit of sacrifices, etc. All these are hinted at in the verse "With this shall Aaron enter the Holy," and through these merits, he silenced the accuser over Israel.

Similarly, we can interpret the verse "And to his father he sent 'like this,'" indicating that he informed his father that he acted like the Kohen Gadol on Yom Kippur, and through all these merits hinted at in the word "zos," he silenced and subdued the accuser. Therefore, he should not fear coming to Egypt. This is what he hinted to his father with the word "zos," and separately from this, he sent ten donkeys carrying from the best of Egypt.
